title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 54 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 54 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns a zero economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is equal to the average total cost, or ATC = P = $15 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@424F@ .

The response states that the firm earns a zero economic profit and explains that the firm’s average total cost curve is tangent to the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is equal to the average total cost, or ATC = P = $15 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@424F@ .

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate TechnoParts’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $910 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$13×70=$910 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5E75@

The response calculates TechnoParts’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $910 and shows the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$13×70=$910 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5E75@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at that price ($5) the firm will shut down in the short run and/or does not explain it’s because the price is below the average variable cost which means the firm does not generate enough revenue to pay for its variable costs, so the firm loses more by producing, in the short run, than shutting down and just paying its fixed cost.

The response states that at that price ($5) the firm will shut down in the short run and explains it’s because the price is below the average variable cost which means the firm does not generate enough revenue to pay for its variable costs, so the firm loses more by producing, in the short run, than shutting down and just paying its fixed cost.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the new average total cost as $18 and/or does not show the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $14×70+$280 70 =$18 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7BFA@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$14+ $280 70 =$18 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7F5B@

The response calculates the new average total cost as $18 and shows the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $14×70+$280 70 =$18 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7BFA@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$14+ $280 70 =$18 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7F5B@

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, Faradaze does not have a dominant strategy and/or does not explain that when TechnoParts chooses to lower its price, Faradaze’s payoff is higher if it does not advertise ( $9,500 > $3,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@435D@ ), and when Techno parts chooses to maintain its price, Faradaze’s payoff is higher if it advertises ( $8,500 > $6,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@435F@ ); therefore, Faradaze does not have a dominant strategy.

The response states that no, Faradaze does not have a dominant strategy and explains that when Techno Parts chooses to lower its price, Faradaze’s payoff is higher if it does not advertise ( $9,500 > $3,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@435D@ ), and when TechnoParts chooses to maintain its price, Faradaze’s payoff is higher if it advertises ( $8,500 > $6,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@435F@ ); therefore, Faradaze does not have a dominant strategy.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Nash equilibrium as TechnoParts maintains its price and Faradaze advertises with payoffs of ($4,000, $8,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FA@ , and/or does not explain that if TechnoParts chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $4,000 to $3,000, and if Faradaze chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $8,500 to $6,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies Nash equilibrium as TechnoParts maintains its price and Faradaze advertises with payoffs of ($4,000, $8,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FA@ , and explains that if TechnoParts chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $4,000 to $3,000, and if Faradaze chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $8,500 to $6,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and/or does not explain that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for TechnoParts to maintain its price and Faradaze to advertise with payoffs of ($4,000, $8,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FA@ because if TechnoParts chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $4,000 to $3,750 ( =$3,000 + $750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42A1@ ), and if Faradaze chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $8,500 to $6,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explain that with the offer TechnoParts’ dominant strategy will continue to be to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher ( $2,000> $1,750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B3@ and $4,000> $3,750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B7@ ) and since Faradaze has no dominant strategy it is better off to not advertise ( $8,500> $6,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42BC@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for TechnoParts to maintain its price and Faradaze to advertise with payoffs of ($4,000, $8,500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FA@ because if TechnoParts chooses to lower its price, its payoff will decrease from $4,000 to $3,750 ( =$3,000 + $750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42A1@ ), and if Faradaze chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $8,500 to $6,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explains that with the offer TechnoParts’ dominant strategy will continue to be to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher ( $2,000> $1,750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B3@ and $4,000> $3,750 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B7@ ) and since Faradaze has no dominant strategy it is better off to not advertise ( $8,500> $6,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42BC@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
